ORIGINAL ARTICLE NephrolDialTransplant(2021)36: 20002007 doi: 10. 1093/ndt/gfab017 AdvanceAccesspublication2February2021 Downloaded from by guest on 31 December 2025 KEY LEARNING POINTS What is already known about this subject? men with chronic Kidney disease (chronic kidney disease) have faster progression of chronic kidney disease as compared with women; studies analysing sex-related difference in chronic kidney disease progression have provided conflicting results on Blood Hypertension (blood pressure) control based on office measurement; and despite the fact that ambulatory blood pressure (ABP) is superior to office blood pressure in correctly diagnosing hypertension and predicting adverse outcome in chronic kidney disease population, no study has addressed the impact of sex on the relationship between ABP and outcome in non-Dialysis chronic kidney disease population. What this study adds? daytime and nighttime blood pressure were significantly higher in men than in women, while office blood pressure was similar. Consequently, men showed higher prevalence of masked hypertension while a white coat effect was prominent among women; ABP goal (daytime135/85 and nighttime blood pressure120/70mmHg) was achieved less frequently in men (25.

1% versus 39. 1%), while no sex-difference was detected in office blood pressure at goal. Consequently, men showed higher prevalence of masked uncontrolled hypertension and sustained hypertension; and over 10. 7years of follow-up, men showed higher risk of end-stage Kidney disease and all-cause mortality; this association was attenuated and become not significant after adjusting for the sex-difference in ABP control, while adjustment for office blood pressure did not change results. What impact this may have on practice or policy? this study highlights the importance of ABP monitoring as essential evaluation in men and women with chronic kidney disease. control58.
